content: christmas bauble #1 ​by richard jones thank you for downloading this pattern i would love to hear from you with any comments on this pattern i have always found following traditional crochet patterns not the most enjoyable part of crocheting i like to get an image in my head of how the pattern will look when done and what part i am working on now if the pattern has repeating motifs i find it very helpful to know something like now we re working on the bottom of the pineapple it helps me to not second guess the instructions and understand why it s telling me to do something even better than textual patterns are the crochet chart style patterns with these you get a good quick representative overview of what the finished product will look like and i find it is easy to see what part you re working on at each step this christmas bauble has a nice simple rhythm to it and once you get going you will only occasionally need to check back to the chart i have given some written instructions but hopefully you will not miss the detailed traditional instructions contact me at ravelry superfantastico or directly at rickardo fantastico@gmail com christmas bauble #1 supplies #10 mercerized cotton 1 6mm us size 6 hook fabric starch balloon preferably white stitches st nothing fancy here just chains chain and double crochets double_crochet oh also a few singles single_crochet and slips sl when finishing a round as i said in the introduction this is a chart centric pattern the text is just for extra detail refer to the chart when in doubt starching i would highly recommend using a white balloon for this i once used a red balloon and it stained the white thread pink so that sucked you might notice in the photo i actually used a yellow balloon this time i washed it carefully first and took a chance this time it worked out but if you can get white balloons that would be much safer so after you ve finished crocheting the bauble insert the ballon into it with the opening right at the top inflate the balloon and hold it closed while you check that it is inflating the bauble evenly sometime the balloon is a bit skew and that can make a bumpy bauble no one wants that so if it s all smooth then tie off the balloon i use standard laundry starch undiluted and it has been fine for me i have seen some people use mod podge if you try that let me know how it works out anyway hang the inflated bauble over the sink and dowse thoroughly with the starch and rub it all over to make sure it gets everywhere then leave to dry overnight once the starch is all dry poke the balloon through the gaps to get it to release from the thread then pop the balloon and extract it carefully instructions
